contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Wandjina rock art.jpg|thumb|right|Wandjina [[rock art]]]] {{For|the ABC-TV series|Wandjina!}} In [[Aboriginal mythology]], the '''Wondjina''' (or '''Wandjina''') were [[cloud]] and [[rain]] spirits who, during the [[Dream time]], created or influenced the landscape and its inhabitants.<ref>This site contains some examples of Wondjina folklore: [http://www.australianstamp.com/Coin-web/feature/history/abdream.htm www. australianstamp. com/Coin-web/feature/history/abdream.htm]</ref> When they found the place they would die, they painted their images on [[cave]] walls and entered a nearby waterhole. The Wondjina style dates from around 3800 [[Before Present|B.P.]], following the end of a millennium long drought that gave way to a wetter climate characterised by regular monsoons.<ref>McGowan H, Marx S, Moss P, Hammond A. Evidence of ENSO mega-drought triggered collapse of prehistory Aboriginal society in northwest Australia. GEOPHYSICAL RESEARCH LETTERS, VOL. 39, L22702, 5 PP., 2012 doi:10.1029/2012GL053916 [http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/2012/2012GL053916.shtml]</ref> Today, certain Aboriginal people of the [[Mowanjum Community|Mowanjum]] tribes repaint the images to ensure the continuity of the Wondjina's presence.<ref> {{cite book | author = Flood, Josephine | title = Rock Art of the Dreamtime | year = 1997 }}</ref> Annual repainting in December or January also ensures the arrival of the monsoon rains, according to [[Mowanjum Community|Mowanjum]] belief.<ref> {{cite book | author = Akerman, Kim & Ryan, Judith | title = Images of Power: Aboriginal Art of the Kimberley | year = 1993 }} p.12</ref> Repainting has occurred so often that at one site the paint is over 40 layers deep. The painting style evolves during this process: the figures of recent years are stockier and some now possess eyelashes.<ref> {{cite book | author = Mulvaney, John & Kamminga, Johan | title = Prehistory of Australia | year = 1999 }} p.405</ref> The Wondjina paintings have common colors of black, red and yellow on a white background. They appear alone or in groups, vertically or horizontally depending on the dimensions of the rock, and can be depicted with figures and objects like the [[Rainbow Serpent]] or [[Yam (vegetable)|yams]]. Common composition is with large upper bodies and heads that show eyes and nose, but typically no mouth. Two explanations have been given for this: they are so powerful they do not require speech<ref> [http://www.mowanjumarts.com/history.html www. mowanjumarts. com/history.html] </ref> and if they had mouths, the rain would never cease. Around the heads of Wondjina are lines or blocks of color, depicting lightning, clouds or rain. The Wondjina can punish those who break the law with floods, lightning and cyclones.<ref> {{cite book | author = Flood, Josephine | title = Rock Art of the Dreamtime | year = 1997 }}</ref> The paintings are still believed to possess these powers and therefore are to be approached and treated respectfully. Each site and painting has a name. In 2007, [[graffiti]] depictions of Wandjina appeared in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Western Australia]]. Styles ranged from stencil-work to a spray painted Wondjina driving a pink car. Using [[flickr]] and [[blogs]], several people engaged in 'Wondjina watching', documenting the Wondjina graffiti they found.<ref> [http://perth.norg.com.au/2007/01/05/watching_the_wandjina/ perth.norg.com. au/2007/01/05/watching_the_wandjina/]</ref> These 'wandering Wondjina' angered and upset Aboriginals who said that only certain of their people are permitted to depict the Wondjina.<ref> [http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/wandering-wandjinas-mystery/story-e6frg13u-1111112784667 www. perthnow.com. au/news/western-australia/wandering-wandjinas-mystery/story-e6frg13u-1111112784667]</ref> A short film, ''Who Paintin' Dis Wandjina'', discussed the Aboriginal reaction.<ref>[http://www.creativespirits.info/resources/movies/who-paintin-dis-wandjina.html www. creativespirits. info/resources/movies/who-paintin-dis-wandjina.html]</ref> == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Australian Aboriginal mythology]]
